explanations.A: It looks like you might have worked out the interest as if the amount earned each year is the same. With compound interest the interest at the end of the first year is added to the account so in the second year the interest is different. Can you think of a formula to use for this?
explanations.B: We have an interest rate of 5% which is a multiplier of 1.05. The money is in the account for 4 years so we raise the multiplier to the power of 4 and multiply by £13000. This gives us the total in the account at the end of 4 years. Finally we subtract the initial amount invested to see what the interest is that has been paid :£13000 × 1.05⁴ - £13000 = £2801.58.
explanations.C: It looks like you might have used simple interest to find the value of the final investment. Notice that we need to use compound interest calculations here, and we are only working out the interest added.
explanations.D: It looks like you have used the correct interest calculation, but given the full final amount and not just the interest earned.
